Posts.Content: My current PSA one year after Brachy is 1.8, which is slightly up from 3 months ago. Just talked to my doc and he said that the PSA will tend to bounce around so do not worry at this time and keep getting a PSA test every 3 months.

Posts.Content: I am feeling pretty good about this, and just had to tell you all my latest PSA. 9 months after Brachytherapy my PSA as of June 16th is....."1.3" Yeah!!! Never had incontinence, I am up urinating 4-5 times a night. Still on Flomax. ED is treated by Cialis (as needed) and it is working. All in all I feel good!

Posts.Title: Latest PSA 9 months after Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: I had my Brachytherapy last Sept and so far so good. As was brought out, brachytherapy is recommended for low grade to low intermediate PC. I know about 5 guys in that boat, that have opted for brachy and all are doing well. I know that there are a lot of variables with PC as in other cancers but when I was doing my research, I found that the life expectancy at 10yrs (and I believe there was also a 15yr study) was the same as if surgery was chosen. The recovery time and side effects are also a lot less than surgery. Granted you still have your prostate, but I have no regrets having the brachytherapy done. I will be going to the doc every 3 months for 2 yrs with a PSA chk each time. My second apt is this month.

AgeInfo.Phrase: that the life expectancy at 10yrs  and I believe there was

Posts.Title: Brachy Therapy vs. Surgery

Posts.Content: This is my first post. I was diagnosed 6-10-13. I met with my urologist (who does open surgery) and he explained all my options, and strongly suggested a 2nd opinion, and read the book by Dr Walsh, which I did. I then traveled to Stanford Cancer Center and met with a robotic doctor and received more information. My next step was to travel to the Seattle Prostate Institute and met with a doctor who explained about Brachytherapy. He explained their procedure and how it compared with the other options. I was very undecided, jumping from one option then another and very stressed out. After hearing what the Seattle Prostate Institute said it was like a light came on and that was it, LDR Brachytherapy is what I picked. My procedure is tentitively set for 9/3. They told me what to expect, but of course I am still a little nervous, but just making a decision has taken a lot of stress off of me. Has anyone gone through LDR Brachytherapy? The doc said the recovery is not bad for about 95% of guys.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter 1outof6, Sorry you are joining our club but welcome. For your stats, Brachy is a great choice. Seattle Prostate Institute is one of the best Brachy centers in the US. You cannot go wrong using their service, especially Dr. Grimm. I would ask for Dr. Grimm if he is available. When I was trying to decide on treatment, he was my top Brachy option. However, most likely they have many good radiation oncologists that he trained and they should be very acceptable too. Good luck. Dr. Grimm has left the Seattle Prostate Institute but I believe he is still in Seattle.Thank you for your wish of good luck. As you know the unknown can be very scary.

Posts.Title: After much thought, Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank Hi there, I had brachytherapy in March 2013 - 66 Pd-103 seeds. It was an agonizing decision of bouncing between the three modalities (with all their variations) but I finally settled on brachytherapy because, based on research, I strongly feel that brachytherapy is near being the "Gold Standard" for treating PCa. My top three concerns were/are: cancer control continence sexual function (although as crazy as it sounds - and it does sound crazy but a lot of men feel this way - this is almost #1 for me) I was riddled with anxiety pre-surgery (I never had surgery before). Once I received the IV pre-surgery 'cocktail' (I believe it was Versed) they could have done anything to me. Shortly afterward, they wheeled me into the surgery room and the anesthesiologist put me out. I woke up a bit groggy about an hour later. As soon as I could pee, I was allowed to leave and my wife drove us home. I burned for about 2-3 days when I urinated (catheter burn). That's it. I was sore but needed no medication outside of an occasional Tylenol. The doctor put me on Rapaflo to help me urinate (which I am now weening off of without too much of a problem). Sexual function: Erections are strong. No medication needed for them. If anything, my sex life has gotten better post-cancer. I feel stronger and harder than ever - "harder than penitentiary steel." My desire has increased. The only disquieting thing about sex was orgasms with little to no ejaculate. It took me some time to get used to it but we were having sex a few weeks post-surgery. I was concerned about shooting one of the seeds out of me but they're stranded together these days so little chance of that. Continence: I have no real urinary issues. Cancer control: My PSA was cut in half first post-brachytherapy PSA. I get another one in about a month or so. I consider myself cured. Time will tell the tale. Sometimes if feels like *something* is going *in there* but this is the radiation working. It feels like a low sort of burning. Good luck. I am sure you will be fine and afterward be happy you picked brachytherapy. Thank you Blank for the information on your Brachytherapy. The more I know going in the better I feel. Your progress sounds great! I do not know as yet the number of seeds or the strength, but he did say that they were stranded and that being stranded he could place them closer to the edge to prevent positive margins. I forgot to ask and can't figure out how they get "stranded" seeds in without an inscision? As for the burning urination, the doc's nurse told me she has heard guys describe the first urnination as "pissing fire" or "pissing razor blades" but she assured me that the burning will decrease and to drink a lot. Blank, may I ask you about how old you are? And again congradulations on your great progress, I hope to be right behind you!
Posts.Signature: Age 67,Viet Nam Vet; PSA 1/08=4.06 7/08=4.8 1/09=7.11 11/09=6.19 2/10=5.94 7/10=6.51 1/11=6.80 6/11=6.58 3/12=8.12 4/12=7.38 10/12=8.05 4/13=8.44; DRE Neg; Biopsy 6/13, 11 cores, Prostate Right=benign Prostate Left=adenocarcinoma, gleason 3+4=7 in two of five cores.Less thatn 5%,2MM total length in ONE gland; T1C;Two additional Pathology reports confirmed above. Posts.Title: After much thought, Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: In a new research paper (dated August 30,2013) the author states there is evidence that when prostate cancer is slow growing it will not proceed to the more aggressive type. If this is true?? it will most likely change the way we deal with PC. The author does say at the end of the paper that more research is needed. The concept to me is intriguing.Remember research papers are a dime a dozen,but they are interesting and to me it is better to stay informed. Here is the first part of the paper: Home » Genitourinary Cancer » Prostate Cancer EMAIL | PRINT | PDF | REPRINT | SHARE FacebookStumbleuponTweet thisRESEARCH REPORT Aggressiveness of Prostate Tumors May Not Change as Cancer Evolves By Anna Azvolinsky, PhD1 | August 30, 2013 1Freelance Science Writer and Cancer Network Contributor. Follow Her on Twitter -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Prostate tumors may not readily evolve from low to high grade, according to a research study published in Cancer Research. Kathryn Penney, ScD, epidemiologist at the Harvard School of Public Health and the Channing Division of Network Medicine at Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston, and colleagues show that the aggressiveness of a prostate tumor could be established at the time of tumor formation. The results have important clinical implications for prostate cancer patients and clinicians when deciding on whether to choose active surveillance or treatment. If the aggressiveness of a tumor does not change drastically in the course of the disease, patients diagnosed with early-stage and low-grade prostate tumors may be more likely to avoid overtreatment and choose surveillance. See the whole article here: http://www.cancernetwork.com/prostat...=1&ts=04092013

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer, aggressive vs slow growing

Posts.Content: I am scheduled for LDR brachytherapy on Sept 4. My doc started me on Cialis a week before the procedure, 5mg every day. After the 2nd day my lower back started to ache,and it was worse at night in bed resulting in little sleep. I just thought that I had strained my back. After the 3rd day my back got worse and my legs felt sore like I had the flu.I could not sleep tossing and turning all night.After the 3rd day of Cialis I quit taking it. Last night (4th night) the pain was still there, took a couple of ibuprofen and laid on the heating pad, that seemed to help. No more Cialis for me. I have not told the doc about this yet so I do not know what he will say. I am supposed to start Flomax on Monday. Has anyone else expierienced this side effect from Cialis?
Posts.Signature: Age 67,Viet Nam Vet; PSA 1/08=4.06 7/08=4.8 1/09=7.11 11/09=6.19 2/10=5.94 7/10=6.51 1/11=6.80 6/11=6.58 3/12=8.12 4/12=7.38 10/12=8.05 4/13=8.44; DRE Neg; Biopsy 6/13, 11 cores, Prostate Right=benign Prostate Left=adenocarcinoma, gleason 3+4=7 in two of five cores.Less thatn 5%,2MM total length in ONE gland; T1C;Two additional Pathology reports confirmed above. Posts.Title: Cialis=Back pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jassythedog Hi Some 8 weeks post LP operation I had the same problem with Cialis plus really bad heartburn. It took 2-3 days to finally get back to normal as the half life of Cialis is around 17 hours. I gave it a while and tried again with the same results. Viagra has been offered but is short lived for intercourse, I was hoping to help recovery by using Cialis, instead I am now using a penis pump. Only pain now is when the the rings snap around the shaft, ooh that hurts. All the best Tony Thanks, I was wondering how long this would stay in my system, guess I will have to wait another couple of days......

Posts.Title: Cialis=Back pain

Posts.Content: Kens, Every one here has very good info on PC. The bottom line is to listen to all and do a lot of research on your own. Get opinions from your own doc then second and third opinions from other docs. Read Dr Walsh's book, surviving prostate cancer (get the latest edition). My brother in law at age 50 had PC 3+3=6 and opted for brachytherapy, this was 5 years ago and he is very pleased with his choice. The last I checked Brachytherapy has the same 15yr survival rate as surgery. Living where you do in S. Cal you have a wealth of good docs, hospitals, and universities. We all know that making a final decision on a procedure is very stressful to say the least, I recall when I finally made mine, about 3 months after the biopsy, it was like a weight being lifted from me.............good luck to you.

AgeInfo.Phrase: brother in law at age 50 had PC 3 3=6 and

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jassythedog Hi Some 8 weeks post LP operation I had the same problem with Cialis plus really bad heartburn. It took 2-3 days to finally get back to normal as the half life of Cialis is around 17 hours. I gave it a while and tried again with the same results. Viagra has been offered but is short lived for intercourse, I was hoping to help recovery by using Cialis, instead I am now using a penis pump. Only pain now is when the the rings snap around the shaft, ooh that hurts. All the best Tony Thanks, I was wondering how long this would stay in my system, guess I will have to wait another couple of days......

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I was diagnosed 6-10-13. I met with my urologist (who does open surgery) and he explained all my options, and strongly suggested a 2nd opinion, and read the book by Dr Walsh, which I did....I met with my urologist (who does open surgery) and he explained all my options, and strongly suggested a 2nd opinion, and read the book by Dr Walsh, which I did. I then traveled to Stanford Cancer Center and met with a robotic doctor and received more information....
